newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: ISO head sees S.Africa keeping up sugar exports.
newsitem.headline: ISO head sees S.Africa keeping up sugar exports.

text.p: South Africa has big potential to increase sugar production and keep annual exports at over a million tonnes, the executive director of the International Sugar Organisation said on Friday.

"After four years of drought and bad crops, South Africa is back again. One million tonnes of (sugar) exports puts South Africa in the premier league," Peter Baron told Reuters in the Indian Ocean port city of Durban.
"In the future South Africa will be exporting around a million tonnes or even more. I think this will be a permanent pattern because the potential, technology and knowledge are here," he said.
"South Africa has big potential to increase production but this should only be done in line with an expanding market," he added.
He said South African production for 1995/96 (October- September) was estimated at 2.4 million tonnes, of which about one milllion tonnes would be exported.
Baron, on his first official visit to the country, said South Africa should concentrate on exporting to Middle Eastern and African countries which had high market potential.
He repeated comments made earlier this month that an estimated 5.5 million tonne surplus on international markets during 1995/96 should put a downward pressure on sugar prices.
Among the countries which had contributed to the surplus were Brazil, Thailand, Australia, India and South Africa.
He said it was possible that the Indian government might licence the sale of part of its large sugar stocks in addition to the one million tonnes it was already exporting.
"I wouldn't be surprised if the Indian government does licence another few hundred thousand tonnes of sugar for export," he said.
An important market being watched was China, which imports about 1.5 million tonnes annually, which will probably increase the future, he said.
"China, for the coming years, will be a considerable importer and will import one to two million tonnes a year over the next five or six years."
Baron said the two new mills in the Middle East would increase their demand for raw sugar and limit imports of refined sugar from the European Union (EU).

"Since the EU is not a raw exporter it will struggle to find alternative markets," he said, adding new markets for the EU could be found in Eastern Europe which was a large importer, in some instances importing as much sugar as China.
He said recent moves in Russia to establish a private sugar association would "have a very positive effect on the Russian economy."
